reviewText:
Early Access Review

Dungeon Souls is an indie action RPG with roguelike elements. In this game, you play as one of six adventurers, including a Barbarian, Archer, and more. You must activate Marks along the dungeon floor in order to advance deeper into the depths in search of the Soul Orb, the only way to regain your soul. Every few levels, you'll come across a deadly boss who will drop epic loot if you can defeat them. You'll need powerful items and your own skills to survive and succeed.

The game draws inspiration from games like Risk of Rain, Nuclear Throne, Overture, BitVenture and Shoot First. The gameplay is easy to learn but tough to master. There are three main elements: an autoattack and two special skills with some cooldowns. Items gained can passively increase your characters stats or add special procs to your attacks. Killing enemies yields EXP points to level up and increase your base stats and gems for purchasing items from shops. There's a good amount of variety among the items and enemies that can be found, and the boss battles are frenetic and challenging. In true roguelike fashion, the game is definitely hard, no matter what difficulty level you choose. However, it isn't as RNG-dependent as most other games are, and it definitely rewards skillful play. There is also permadeath, so you can't save progress between runs. However, money that you accumulate is kept and can be used to permanently upgrade your favorite characters, which balances some of the difficulty you can have when starting fresh.

At the time that this review was posted, the game is still in Early Access. Though the game is fully playable and is totally fun and enjoyable, it isn't a perfect release. Some of the elements are very unbalanced, such as traps and the melee classes. Playing as either one of them can almost guarantee a swift death as they are ridiculously underpowered compared to the other characters. Traps like sliding spike-balls and triggered boulders can quickly end a run. Though I've never experienced any, players in the forums have reported some game-breaking bugs or can't even run/download the game.

Still, the developer, Mike Studios, is dedicated and is constantly tweaking the game. Before release on Steam, Dungeon Souls has gained a notable fan-following on other gaming sites, such as itch.io, Indie DB, and Game Jolt. All in all, the game is good in its current state and is definitely worth buying now if you're a fan of hack n' slash, roguelites, and dungeon crawlers.

TL; DR: For fans of Risk of Rain, Nuclear Throne, and The Binding of Isaac.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Taking inspiration from Binding of Isaac and Risk of Rain, Dungeon Souls is looking to make its mark in the field of roguelites or games with rogue elements. As of right now it does not quite stand as tall as what inspired it, but it is a great game nonetheless.

The rogue gallery of silhouettes players see when starting a new game is an enticing tease. The three starting characters are berserker, archer, and thief archetypes that each feel very different both in stats and in how they attack. In addition to stats making characters different, characters’ basic attacks are melee or ranged, with varied ranges for either and projectiles that behave differently for ranged characters.  Each character has two skills that can be unlocked with level ups besides the basic attack they get from the start, and players get a skill point every few levels. The skills range from a gate that multiplies projectiles and summoning skeletons to a frenzied state or raining arrows on foes.

Characters are not that hard to unlock, with some requiring luck and others requiring a bit of skill. However, once your roster is full there is an incentive to push forward. Cumulative experience upgrades each characters “neophyte level” with a rank of 5 stars. Each rank upgrades stats by a percent and at the highest ranks grants players an extra stat point on level up, and a brand new costume that, for most characters, looks incredibly spiffy.

In addition to the neophyte levels offering some mitigation to the grind cycle of dying, there is also some light crafting and some upgrades to passives that apply to all characters. The crafting requires players to obtain recipes from a secret level (which can be time consuming) and hunt down the proper materials, but there seems to be little pay off for this right now. The upgraded passives are quite potent but unnecessary, though movement speed increases just make the experience smoother. However, the game can be beaten without too much hassle even with all of these boosts, in fact due to the game not holding the player’s hand, I didn’t know these mechanics existed until after I had already beaten it with a few different characters.

The rewards found in chests and by defeating bosses are mostly safe options. Flat damage or defense increases, with some items being able to stack. Getting duplicates of items pass their max stack rank (and some will not stack at all) gives players experience, gold, or crafting materials instead. Most of the items are useful, while others seem questionable, but none of them are quite game changing like Epic/Dr. Fetus or Ancient Scepter.

The dungeons you crawl through are dark and some of the enemies are fairly familiar. Players are tasked with fighting off ghosts and skeletons in the beginning areas named appropriately Dark Dungeon, but soon they will find themselves fighting yetis and beholders in slightly different areas (with the exception of a tundra like area that stands out the most). Every 3rd level pits players against a boss that has a few abilities and they all summon extra enemies to fight. These boss fights seem to be most closely inspired by, albeit on a much tamer field, bullet hells: even with high survivability, dodging a maze of projectiles while trying to return damage is the key to victory.

Though there is quite a bit of content present already, there seems to be just a few things missing in the current state. It seems that there still needs to be a true final boss (simply referred to as “her” by every other boss), and currently the game just loops over again with increased difficulty after beating the current final boss. Right now with a few dozen hours put in (not a completely accurate time as I have had to leave the game running for hours while paused. Also, this is a good time to mention that pausing is a feature) I have nearly every character fully ranked, some unused recipes and I am fairly positive I have obtained every item multiple times. As great as the classes are now, some could use a bit of tweaking or balance, and I would love to have more classes in general. The class depth right now is good (with the basic attacks, stats, and skills all being different), but the early access statement on the store page says that there will be more abilities to choose from in the future. Really the largest complaint is that I have enjoyed the game so much that I just want more of it in general.

With a large update of multiplayer and a final boss coming, as well as the possibility of more content, Dungeon Souls is great game that is probably going to get even better.

*Review in progress, will update as game grows or leaves early access.

Dungeon Souls is a top-down rogue-like dungeon crawler that draws inspiration from titles like Nuclear Throne, but ramps up the difficulty to an intense degree. I think this is best exemplified by their Hero Select screen, where you get to choose from three fallen heroes. You’re already dead at character select. That’s how tough this is, and they’re not trying hide that fact with anything more than a cute pixelated throwback to games of yesteryear.

There are three heroes to choose from, initially, each with their own unique skills that lend towards different playstyles. You have the Barbarian, for those that enjoy rushing into things head first, cleaving your way through baddies in a blood frenzied rage. Then, you have the Archer, who takes a more cautious approach by raining down arrows on their enemies from afar. Lastly, you have the Thief, for those of you more prone to sneaking around to find best position before you put a knife or bomb in just the right place. There are also five other heroes to be unlocked on your journey, but those are up to you to find.

Regardless of which hero you pick, this game takes a bit of caution and strategy as you wade through procedurally generated dungeons filled with waves of respawning baddies. Your goal in each dungeon is to collect as much loot, equipment and experience to level up enough to ready yourself for the next dungeon. As you level, you can custom tailor your character by spending points in attributes, and between your three skills. This allows a lot of unique builds that you have to take into consideration as you come to face greater foes in each dungeon.

In order to advance from one dungeon to the next, you have to active several glyphs which summon monsters all around you. Once all the glyphs are activated, you open a gate to the next dungeon, repeating the process until you reach the boss. These fights are where the game starts to feel like as skilled as you may be, you need a little bit of luck on your side as well. As you progress through each dungeon, you’ll get random drops from defeated foes, which can be something as simple as a medicinal herb, to something as powerful as a spiked, magically enchanted suit of armor. It’s all luck of the draw, and I didn’t feel too lucky as I progressed.

This game isn’t just difficult, it’s brutal, and most of it seems intentional. As you clear sectors of a dungeon, enemies respawn in your wake, which can leave you wondering if you should move on, or stick around and grind for more experience. This choice is made for you if you activate all the glyphs, which summons an undefeatable guardian that will sap your life from you until you move through the gate. This mechanic left me wondering what the developers had intended for their players to do, since they left open the possibility to grind, while ushering you out quickly once you’ve completed the level.

While this game did hold me at bay with it’s difficulty, I rarely felt punished, as if it were unavoidable. I just kept hacking away, learning the timings of the different enemies and adjusting my builds to suit my needs and playstyle. The mechanics were solid, leaving me with no complaints about hitboxes, animations or bugs, but there was a certain gameplay element that was incredibly irritating. Hallways. Time and time again, I was forced to walk through a long corridor taking countless hits from off-screen enemies that could see me across the entirety of the map. I can see why this happens, with the levels being procedurally generated and all, but I did feel cheated out of a few good runs because of it.

The only other complaint I had was the music, which was a single, atmospheric song that repeated through each dungeon I encountered. It is still the beta, though, and this could change, along with many other aspects of the game. All and all, I think that Dungeon Souls is another solid game that’s helping breathe life into the rogue-like genre. It’s still a little rough around the edges, but with a little polishing, this could be quite the gem.

IntroductionWhenever I see a game these days with the name ‘Souls’ in it I get a little bit anxious. A lot of games try to emulate the vibe and/or difficulty of the Dark/Demon Souls games (hence the ‘Souls’ part in the title). As you can judge by the screenshots the vibe isn’t what Dungeon Souls is aiming for, but is it tough-as-nails then? Or is it something else entirely and have I completely misjudged it by looking at its name alone?

GameplayI can happily tell you that - while there are some similarities, like pretty much every game – Dungeon Souls is nothing like the Souls series from From Software. Oh, it *is* hard, mind you, so I guess I was right about that, though. No, if I had to compare it to a different game, then I would sooner compare it to The Binding Of Isaac or Risk Of Rain. That is correct; we have a roguelike game on our hands here.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=528494187
Most likely you will just start off running around the moment you spawn (there are several classes to choose from, by the way), hoping and praying that you know what you’re doing, but it probably won’t take long before your first official death. The game can get a bit hectic too soon and if you don’t exactly know what to do yet, or what effects an item will have on you (you usually don’t have enough time to stand still and properly read the descriptions) then you have basically already lost your first game. And then you retry again – because it’s a roguelike – and try to do better this time. And you will probably succeed in doing this, because you start to learn more about the world, the enemies and the items each and every time you play.
But every now and then, when things seem to go so well, the game intentionally decides to ruin one of your games by unleashing a trap on you when you’re in a small room with tons of enemies around. Sigh…

Ultimately the goal is to activate all of the marks in a level to open up the portal that will transport you to the next level. Activating a mark will always spawn a group of enemies, so you better be prepared and clear the room before you activate it. Killing enemies will level up your character, which allows you to unlock (a) skill(s). Enemies will become tougher, too, of course, so it balances out nicely eventually. Most of the time. But your enemies can still hit hard unfortunately and your health bar can be drained in a matter of seconds if you’re not careful enough, or if the game just thinks it’s time for you to die. It’s definitely challenging and without a doubt can be considered hard. Maybe even *too* hard. Thankfully this is still in an Early Access state so the difficulty can still be fine-tuned before the final release, but if you’re looking for a casual experience you better continue your search for now.

There are apparently 4 different environments and every few levels (if I’m not mistaken: 3) you will face a boss. Each level can take up to 5-10  minutes to complete usually, but time is of the essence: once all marks have been activated a timer will countdown and if it hits zero a ‘redeemer’ will appear who will chase you down and drain your health until you’re either dead or have proceeded through the portal. This feature was also available in Risk Of Rain and I didn’t really like it there either. There’s no need for rushing people through the game. Let people take their time and find out what can still be found and done here and there before they decide to finally move on to the next area. You want people to appreciate the work you put into the graphics and lore, don’t you? Well…, maybe you don’t. In any case, there are other ways to increase the difficulty.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=528494145
Items you find during your quest to victory are random each time you play and you might not know about the effects of a specific item until you have actually used it. The results can be either helpful or critical/deathly but one thing is certain: it adds to the tense atmosphere. Will you risk using an item early on and hope it will make your life easier for maybe just a few minutes or will you save it for a different occasion, but risk that you might die before you’ll be able to use it? The risk/reward mechanic is generally speaking a good and fun feature to have, as long as it’s been implemented well. In this case it has been, sort of, but there’s always room for improvement. Especially considering the current difficulty. Because of it there absolutely needs to be some tweaking.

Audio & VisualsNot much to say about the sounds effects (nothing bad, at least) but the game only seems to have one, constantly repeated, track right now. That’s very limited and bound to annoy some people after a while.

Onto the graphics: the graphics are vibrant and reasonably detailed. Everything is also nicely animated. There were a few occasions where I couldn’t make out certain objects, though, but fortunately these moments were very rare. Because of the pixelated graphics things can also get a little hectic whenever there’s happening too much on screen. Pixelated graphics aren’t the best choice in situations like this. However, I can understand the reason why it was chosen, since it can be cost-effective. Other than that it all looks just fine, really. No (further) complaints here.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=528494107
Length/Replay ValueDepending on your skills and luck you could possibly blast through this game in 5-10 hours time. But then you would have to know exactly what you were doing. Most of us won’t be that lucky or smart so let’s say it would take about 5--20 hours before you finished your first game. Since the current price is €10 I’d say that’s more than fair. You can even try it again after that since there are multiple characters to choose from. Plus, the final release will have even more content. Plenty of content to be found here if you’re a roguelike-aficionado.

ConclusionIt’s still a work in progress and it needs more content and tweaking as we speak, but so far it shows promise. It doesn’t really introduce anything new, but I guess that’s to be expected with games in this genre. So if you don’t mind any of that go give it a try or at least add it to your watch- or wishlist.

Don't let my time fool you. Time spent in offline mode does not transfer over when you go online. In actuality I have roughly 40 hours. Needless to say this is a great game if you don't always have internet capabilities.

The non-stop action starts here. Essentially Terraria's Dungeon in the form of a rogue-esque game mixed with the Binding of Isaac. Dungeon Souls is by far one of the better pixalated games on the Steam Marketplace, and it's not even finished! While it may still be buggy, and everything may not be completely sorted out, I enjoy it, and am looking forward to the newer updates that include unlockable characters and multiplayer (hopefully more than just split-screen). Dungeon Souls deserves to thrive on a market filled with games that make the PC Master Race the way it is.

Options: Forgot to mention this previously from the game's release, but in order to change the settings, the game has to reload itself. This could easily be done through real-time.

Ranking: Characters can be ranked up by playing. How much it increases is unknown to me. There should be character-specific perma-upgrades rather than a permanent upgrade across all characters.

Gameplay: Completing the dungeon only increases the amount of enemy spawns, the number of bosses per boss level (correlating to which dungeon number you are on). Instead of spawning more bosses in, create variants much like how the Binding of Isaac creates variants (being faster and slightly weaker, weaker but two of bosses, different attacks or even attack speed). As well as variants we also need substitutes as fighting the same boss over and over again can just become a chore more than an exhilarating fight. Harder bosses or variants should drop better loot. While the elite variant of the boss (overall harder in general) should have a chance to drop unique items (an idea already circulating the forums).

Loot: Before the update that increased the power of spikeballs or eyeballs instead of getting multiples, spikeballs would demolish bosses as they would constantly rush at you. Even more of an Ex: Dungeon 8, eight Skeleton Kings, without even attacking I just moved around the bosses as my buddies circled me. I had to give up and quit after I hit Dungeon 12 after spending six dungeons in a row without attacking in boss fights. So I'm glad that was fixed.

Keep in note that not only is the game is in Early Access, but I was also playing the current build of the time (Update #4).

Early Access Review

Dungeon Souls looks, sounds and feels great. There are a good amount of characters who fit into the classic RPG classes (wizard, barbarian, archer etc) and each has their own playstyle and two active skills. Gameplay involves fighting through randomly generated dungeons, killing enemies and progressing to new areas by defeating bosses.

So far so good, but the game has some serious isssues. The main one is difficulty. The normal enemies (although pleasingly varied) are all EXTREMELY weak, and almost none of them pose any threat to the player. As a result the game becomes dull and repetetive because there is simply no challenge. Boss fights are the only thing that can realistically kill you.

The RPG-esque leveling system - where you earn skill points that can be spent to improve your stats - should offer a tactical element to the game... but unfortunately the enemies are so puny that carefully choosing which skills to improve has little effect on your run. Items are also very generic, mostly offering stat-ups. There's none of the risk/reward element that makes games like the Binding of Isaac so much fun. I've only ever seen one item with a downside, and even this was negligable.

All of this aside, Dungeon Souls is still fun, at least for a while. If the game was rebalanced, given a difficulty boost and had some items nerfed, it could be an absolutely awesome experience. Hopefully the early access label will mean the game will improve in future.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Dungeon Souls is a top-down roguelike rogue-lite hack 'n' slash dungeon crawler. It is similar to Hammerwatch to a degree, so if you like that you will probably like this. The biggest difference between the 2 is that this is strictly single player as of the writing of this review. The game is in early access, so that might change. Generally I avoid early access due to a large amount of them being absolute garbage that will never be finished. I heard good things about this one though so I gave it a shot.

Starting out you have access to 3 characters, the melee based barbarian, the accurate archer, and the fast thief. There are 5 others, which are unlocked by beating certain enemies or finding certain items. There also looks to be more in the works, which will just add to the variety of play options. All the characters are fairly well balanced, none feel noticiably weaker or stronger than others, although they do all play different due to their skills and starting stats. The various characters have different emphasis, but none of them feel like support characters like in Hammerwatch. Please note that I like Hammerwatch a lot, am just explaining the difference. All of them have a basic attack, which is different for each character, and 2 special skills. The skills are unique to the characters as well. The thief for example can throw an AoE bomb and disappear for a couple seconds, while the archer has multi-shot for a few seconds and a devastating arrow rain. There are 4 difficulties, the higher 2 are locked until you beat the game on the previous one.

The music is decent, not bad for a dungeon crawler. But odds are your attacks, explosions, and what not are going to cover it up a lot, not to mention the almost bullet hell like nature of some of the boss fights. Sound effects are very nice. No voice acting but the game doesn't really need it either.

This game lacks in story, but it excels in REALLY FUN gameplay! The items you find from chests or in shops are random and some of them can completely change how you play. Due to items I found in one run I ended up with a tank that was near unkillable as long as I didn't try to die due to all the health regen he got. He died on a boss but until then that was an absolutely amazingly fun run. There are a ton of items that boost stats, give regen, bonus damage, statuses attacks, and other things. The dungeons are randomly generated although the way to move to the next level is set. Find and activate 2-5 large glyphs on the floor and go back to where you started that floor at to move on. Enemies are easy to identify, with them being tinted a different color if they're one of the random ones that are stronger than normal. I've only found one sprite that is overtly reused. A mage type enemy that come in 3 different colors, all of which attack completely differently. The floors are nicely done, and very atmosphereic. Dark enough to make them feel dangerous, but not so dark you can't see the things you're supposed to squish.

The game has a leveling system. Upon level up you get a stat point to put into (physical) damage, defense, magic (damage), speed, resistance, and accuracy. Most characters start with an accuracy of over 70%, 1 starts are 40%, one at 50%. If you are playing a non-melee range character you are going to get that up to 90%+ asap otherwise your attacks have the spread of a shotgun without the damage. You start the game with 1 skill point to toss into your basic attack or to unlock one of the 2 special skills of the character. You get more skill points as you level, but not every level. Both skill and stat points need to be spent wisely or you'll find yourself overwhelmed. Any money you haven't spent at the end of your run is added to the bank at character selection which can be used to buy passive global permanent upgrades for the characters. These upgrades are rather expensive but are very nice, especially for when you unlock the harder modes.

Dungeon Souls is also very easy to run. I do not have a high end PC by any means, and the game runs at a nice and steady 60FPS.

I have a few complaints about the game. First, the character unlocks seem either too quick or too easy. I unlocked 2 of the 5 locked characters on my first run by taking out basic mobs. And had them all unlocked in under 3 hours without actually trying to unlock them. Second, the game could really use a tutorial. It isn't stated anywhere to click on your skills once in a run to apply skill points. It again isn't stated anywhere that you use your potions by hitting the 1-3 keys. Or that you can bounce between special skills (which are used with the right click) by using the mouse wheel instead of Q and E.

Very good game, very fun. If you like the genre I'd say it should definitely be on your list of games to play. And early access status aside, this is a game that I would definitely buy again. I am actually looking forward to seeing the future updates for this game.

I play a lot of Binding of Isaac and Vagante, so this game fits really nicely into my existing repetoire. The art direction is nice, that somewhat common pixel style, but done well with good lighting effects etc.

I honestly can't wait to see how this game improves beyond this point because it's already pretty good.

I have mixed feelings about playing games with controllers, but I actually feel like this game might benefit from it if they can make the targeting system work well (I feel like some games like this require a little too much precise targeting to benefit from it). I only recommend controller support because after playing rogue-likes for a while, it sometimes benefits to have the whole control scheme in your hands so you can sit back in a comfortable chair rather than the upright mouse and keyboard posture.

At this point I give it a solid 10/10 for day 1 of the release and I have no second thoughts or return intentions.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After winning a giveaway, I was stoked to spend some time on this game while recovering from recent hip surgery.  A few hours in and I am quite ecstatic about the gift.

The game is a roguelike and borrows heavily from recent successful titles such as Binding of Isaac, DCSS and even Rogue Legacy with some aspects.  I'm usually a little annoyed by the indie movement of making games look like I'm playing my old Super Nintendo, but this game's does graphics well overall.

The game is very straight forward as you jump in, you have your two mouse buttons, the WASD to move and your Q/E keys for changing out the abilities.  As you level, you can boost certain character stats and your original abilities along with gathering certain items that will make you stronger.

The good -
like stated above, the graphics are solid for what they are and match the game well.
The combat feels nice and your character very responsive.
The character progression is a nice touch, with the characters gaining slight permanent boost to stats the longer you play them.
Unlocking the passive skills with gold is also nice, as it helps you get that extra edge to keep progressing even if you don't have the best luck with drops.
The bad -
At a certain point, boss fights seem very much 'we're going to fill your screen with projectiles until you die' (at least with certain classes).  It doesn't really make it challenging as some items are pretty game breaking still (it is a beta afterall) and you can literally get 100% parry chance and sit there afk and still win.
The class differences are monumental at the beginning until you equalize things with drops.  Yes, you will be able to progress with anything if you take the time to get items and farm enemies for experience if needed, but some feel VERY underpowered in the beginning.
the ability switching is also very clunky.  It would be nice if the e/q buttons activated the abilities as soon as you pressed the keys, or alternatively - take a page out of Path of Exile's book and assign the 2nd ability to the middle mouse button,
probably the weakest complaint, but reskinning enemies to show toughness is something that annoys me a little bit, especially when they are largely still not a challenge unless you're playing the higher difficulties.
The weird/broken:
Some items are beyond broken.  Theif's lockpick is a 25% chance every 30 seconds to unlock every chest on the map.  You simply spam the key before grabbing the last unlock until you can collect every item.  Nothing else in the item slot comes close IMO to this piece until you're maxed out with parry chance and 'unique' drops.
The class discrepancy with the magic/physical aspect is a little annoying to me.  Some characters - let's take the warrior for example - has skills that are boosted by magic damage... why?  Same with the thief and some others.
Many classes simply don't need all three abilities to play different.  They are a little redundant and frankly after 1 levelsare almost pointless to raise higher.  It makes it even worse that your ability levels are so far between and eventually just stop.  It may be better to give you an ability level each time you level up normally, but cap the Q/E abilities a little bit so you can't raise them too high.
I'm not a huge fan of the same enemies spawning every time from the locks.  It takes one AOE ability to take everything out most of the time and it's always the same enemies.  The higher difficulties make this a little better, but once you get enough items it still becomes a cake-walk.  The game, with some classes, effectively becomes a dance with bosses with nothing much in between.
Overall, I would definitely recommend this game if you're a fan of roguelikes.  It has enough replayability with the various classes and progression.  I would like it if the bosses later on had some more interesting mechanics instead of just doubling them up/etc.  Higher difficulties solve a lot of the issues that I have, but are very difficult to play with certain characters even if you are fairly skilled.  I'm sure I will be putting in many more hours into this though.

I wouldn't say that I recommend this game, yet I wouldn't say that I don't.
The game itself is fun, especially when you have a really good build, but it's got so many faults.

For one, the melee classes are abysmally bad. Getting close to enemies is bad enough, but all of melee classes have a slow attack. With the exception of one, but you still have to get close and personal. Which is bad, because it makes fighting ranged enemies tedious. And fighting some of the bosses is impossible because they either move around a lot or getting close will put you in a bad position, making you die faster a Mayfly. It's just better to use a Ranged class, the best example being Archer and Rogue, because of their quick rate of fire, ability to cancel out projectiles by firing at them, and starting off with the most speed.

Another flaw in this game is the fact that it lags (this one is personal). A Pixelated game that LAGS. This is something that I very rarely see. From what I can tell, it's all the dynamic lighting and particle effects from the torches. It could also be the corpses as well, since the farther I get into a level, the more lag there is. This game seems to be trying to be a difficult roguelike, somewhat akin to something like Nuclear Throne and Dark Souls (And not just because of the Souls" in both names). And it achieves that. In all the wrong ways. As Vlambeer

Frantic, tense gameplay mixed with beautiful music, pixel art, and RPG elements – Dungeon Souls is a hectic, punishing ride I love to take.

An indie roguelike RPG with a heavy focus on its gameplay, Dungeon Souls won’t be foreign to those familiar with Hammerwatch or the Binding of Isaac, as the player is pitted into a cruel world where absolutely everything wants to murder you. To survive, the player must run, kill, level up, gather items, master skills, and run and kill some more.

It’s set in a fantasy world where after choosing one of several available character classes, such as the Barbarian, Archer, and Thief, the player must fight their way through hordes of mobs and bosses, gaining powers and facing tougher fights with each floor. Each level is also procedurally generated, making every playthrough unique and vastly more enjoyable had it not been.

One of the greatest strengths of Dungeon Souls is the balance among the character classes. The Barbarian is tough and meant to be tossed into the fray. It deals decent enough damage, but is slower compared to its long-range counterparts. The Thief is light-footed, can deal decent ranged attacks and has the highest critical-hit damage. But, the HP is quite low, along with its defense. Even though they’re vastly different, neither of the classes felt imbalanced, but rather only changed how I approached my game.

The only downside I saw was the lack of co-op. As of now the game is still in Early Access, and the developers state the full version will feature multiplayer. Given that, I do have to knock it down a point for what I played myself at this time. When multiplayer gets up and running I’ll gladly revisit this and adjust accordingly.

9/10. Addictive, well-paced controlled mayhem in a beautiful fantasy setting.

Dungeon Souls a great game that has some great inspiration, and this game is coming along quite nicely. My only real critiques are below:

-As said to death, melee is way outclassed. the weapon size on barbarian is way to small. It's impossible to hit a melee enemy without getting hit. Warrior is manageable, but you have to rely on his ranged ability. Give these classes bigger weapons to balance. Barbarian should be warrior size, and warrior should be a size larger.

-Number on enemies can be ridiculous, especially early game. Wizard handles them with multishot and Cleric does the same, but other classes have trouble with this. I understand preferred playstyle, but compare it to Risk of Rain. Enemies become stronger and more frequent over time. The current system has lead to me watching larger stuff spawn while I deal with crowds of enemies on the first floor.

-Leveling is a pain. You get one statpoint per level, and as far as I've experienced, about one level per floor. Leveling is not a fast process, and should be rewarded more largely. Vice versa, leveling reward could be the same, but leveling could be faster.

-Bosses. I read this in an earlier review and must say that bosses are not impossible, but are one of the greater annoyances in the game. An enemy with 1500 health I'm dealing 7 damage to at a time is tedious. Add constant enemies spawning as I kill them off and attempt to attack the boss is more than most players can handle. Clearly one must be of a higher level to defeat the boss, but as I stated previously, leveling is not properly scaled. Beating a boss right now is the most rewarding feeling in game while overpowered. The statement for bosses is also true in the current version of the game for floors following them. I always feel underleveled when entering floors after a boss, and it usually shows by a swift death.

-Not currently in the game, but there should be some form of tutorial. I know what I'm doing now, but a tutorial would have made the learning curve infinitely easire.

Should I have any other critiques, they will be added, but these are things I would like to see improved right now.

There are some REALLY glaring oversights that make the game not worth playing in its current iteration, which is somewhat understandable for an Early Access Game. Although, why would you bother going to Early Access if your game isn't fun to play yet?!

Most disturbing is the lack of mouse support on the main menu. Without mouse support, the main menu becomes a puzzle in its own right. Arrow keys? No. Press Enter? NOPE. Try the mouse again? Nothing.

You have to use ASWD on the menu. WTF?! But how do you select options, you ask, if it's not enter. With SPACEBAR of course.

After picking from one of three characters (more can be unlocked, to be implemented later I take it), you're dropped into a great pixelated dungeon, usually right on top of enemies. You'll be taking damage from the second you start playing, and it doesn't stop until you die. I mean that. It never stops. Want to spend the point you earned from leveling up? No time. The character sheet nor inventory pause the game. Basically, if you bother to read anything or attempt to understand any nuance of the game, you'll die. Why on God's green earth was this deemed a good idea? I'm not even playing a multiplayer game. I just want a damn second to read what my abilities do. But you don't have a second. Read, and you die. That's the moral of this game.

Also, it lacks controller support. It's a twin stick shooter... that lacks controller support. Let that soak in. I mean, did everyone forget that twin stick shooters were born in the arcade?! That the WHOLE point was to have independent control of movement and shooting via two separate analog joysticks? Hence, twin stick. Why wasn't this game built from the ground up to support controllers? Do they have any hope of releasing to other platforms? They should! Because the design, aesthetic, art are otherwise fantastic. It just suffers from some REALLY bad production decisions.

This game is in VERY early access. It has great potential though. Wait for release, otherwise we're sending developers the wrong message. That message being, Yes

After winning a giveaway, I was stoked to spend some time on this game while recovering from recent hip surgery.  A few hours in and I am quite ecstatic about the gift.

The game is a roguelike and borrows heavily from recent successful titles such as Binding of Isaac, DCSS and even Rogue Legacy with some aspects.  I'm usually a little annoyed by the indie movement of making games look like I'm playing my old Super Nintendo, but this game's does graphics well overall.

The game is very straight forward as you jump in, you have your two mouse buttons, the WASD to move and your Q/E keys for changing out the abilities.  As you level, you can boost certain character stats and your original abilities along with gathering certain items that will make you stronger.

The good -
like stated above, the graphics are solid for what they are and match the game well.
The combat feels nice and your character very responsive.
The character progression is a nice touch, with the characters gaining slight permanent boost to stats the longer you play them.
Unlocking the passive skills with gold is also nice, as it helps you get that extra edge to keep progressing even if you don't have the best luck with drops.
The bad -
At a certain point, boss fights seem very much 'we're going to fill your screen with projectiles until you die' (at least with certain classes).  It doesn't really make it challenging as some items are pretty game breaking still (it is a beta afterall) and you can literally get 100% parry chance and sit there afk and still win.
The class differences are monumental at the beginning until you equalize things with drops.  Yes, you will be able to progress with anything if you take the time to get items and farm enemies for experience if needed, but some feel VERY underpowered in the beginning.
the ability switching is also very clunky.  It would be nice if the e/q buttons activated the abilities as soon as you pressed the keys, or alternatively - take a page out of Path of Exile's book and assign the 2nd ability to the middle mouse button,
probably the weakest complaint, but reskinning enemies to show toughness is something that annoys me a little bit, especially when they are largely still not a challenge unless you're playing the higher difficulties.
The weird/broken:
Some items are beyond broken.  Theif's lockpick is a 25% chance every 30 seconds to unlock every chest on the map.  You simply spam the key before grabbing the last unlock until you can collect every item.  Nothing else in the item slot comes close IMO to this piece until you're maxed out with parry chance and 'unique' drops.
The class discrepancy with the magic/physical aspect is a little annoying to me.  Some characters - let's take the warrior for example - has skills that are boosted by magic damage... why?  Same with the thief and some others.
Many classes simply don't need all three abilities to play different.  They are a little redundant and frankly after 1 levelsare almost pointless to raise higher.  It makes it even worse that your ability levels are so far between and eventually just stop.  It may be better to give you an ability level each time you level up normally, but cap the Q/E abilities a little bit so you can't raise them too high.
I'm not a huge fan of the same enemies spawning every time from the locks.  It takes one AOE ability to take everything out most of the time and it's always the same enemies.  The higher difficulties make this a little better, but once you get enough items it still becomes a cake-walk.  The game, with some classes, effectively becomes a dance with bosses with nothing much in between.
Overall, I would definitely recommend this game if you're a fan of roguelikes.  It has enough replayability with the various classes and progression.  I would like it if the bosses later on had some more interesting mechanics instead of just doubling them up/etc.  Higher difficulties solve a lot of the issues that I have, but are very difficult to play with certain characters even if you are fairly skilled.  I'm sure I will be putting in many more hours into this though.

Early Access Review

Premise:

Clear each level by killing enemies and activating marks to progress deeper into the dungeon.  Acquire equipment from chests and shops to make yourself more powerful.

Death is permanent, but not to fear, the resources and experience you collect from your previous deaths can be used to make your character even more powerful, thus making your character stronger every time you die and revive.  Death is an integral part of finally achieving victory!

Visuals:

A cute little game with retro sprite graphics.  The dungeons have neat little designs everywhere, and the characters are cute and really fun.  There's not exactly much to say, but it still looks really nice.

I greatly appreciate that the dungeon backgrounds change with every boss battle.  Instead of making every dungeon look the same with more powerful enemies of the same type, Dungeon Souls changes the dungeon and enemy sprites every 4th level.  It is always refreshing to find a new color palette after you defeat a difficult boss.

Menus/Interface:

A lot of things aren't exactly explained from the start.  The menus and in-game interface can be a little overwhelming at the beginning.  Most of it must be learned through trial and error, and a lot of fiddling around.  It all works well once you figure it out though.

Gameplay/Controls:

Overall, gameplay is a lot of fun.  Basic gameplay is just running around and just chop at random stuff.  You collect items from your fallen enemies, and every 3 levels you will be faced with a boss; each one being harder than the last.

The fact that death is an integral part of eventual victory makes dying a lot less painful in the long run; you die knowing that, next time, you will most likely level up and progress even farther.  So in this case, what kills you makes you stronger!  (Bad reference, I know)

Also, enemies do appear on top of you randomly, and I find this a little unfair to the player, as players shouldn't be penalized for something that is not in their control.

Controls are very simple and well laid out.  While playing, you have easy access to all your attacks, and it is not difficult to use at all, after you learn how they work of course, and that may take some time.

Certain things I am still unsure of how they work.  We could use a little more of a tutorial with this game, as the one currently in place is not the most informative.  I am assuming they are planning on adding a more clear and informative tutorial as development progresses.

Glitches:

Being in early access, this game does have its fair share of glitches.  At times, the game slows down to around 30 FPS.  Seeing as how the graphics are very simplistic and un-demanding,  this is a little confusing. Another issue I have experienced is a game crash after picking up an item.  Aside from this, I haven't found any other issues.

As this game is in early access, I cannot hold these minor glitches against the game, as it is still a work in progress.

Summary:

A fun game overall.  I recommend this game.

Pros:

-Leveling up after a death adds an element of fun to dying.
-Combat is generally simplistic, but there are certain more advanced things which can be done to tilt combat in your favor.
-Cute graphics.

Cons:

-Some glitches, but nothing game breaking, although the framerate drop is annoying.
-Needs a more informative tutorial. Current tutorial leaves the user hanging.
-Sometimes unfair combat.

SCORE:  8.5 / 10
